utterances: It's a very small movement.
Yeah, then it is more like a train movement than a hammock movement or anything like that.
Wow.
Yeah, so are you going to lengthen your test out to a whole night, do you think?

Yes because this is really the interesting stuff potentially in the future because as you might know, sleep - as everybody knows, sleep is a major problem, a major problem for many people, major problem when growing older.
And basically the response to sleep problem is pharmacology.
And pharmacology is good in the short term.
Pharmacology is not great on the long term.
So it could be an alternative if it works on all nights, which we don't know for the time being.
It could be an alternative to drugs in certain type of sleep problem.
So we need first - before we try it on people who have problems, we need first controls, an entire night, and this is exactly what we are doing now.
Well, Dr. Muhlethaler, thank you very much for taking time to talk with us today, and good luck to you.
Thank you.
Michel Muhlethaler is a professor of neuroscience in the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Geneva, talking to us from Switzerland.
We're going to take a break, and we're going to come back and talk about what happens when robots attack.
You don't want to miss this one.
Stay with us.
We'll be right back.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
I'm Ira Flatow.
This is SCIENCE FRIDAY, from NPR.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
And I'm Madeleine Brand.
This week, I took a little trip to the heart of TV land, Studio City, California, as part of our ongoing coverage of the writers strike now in week three.
We stopped by Art's Deli.
It's an institution.
Half of their business comes from Hollywood, says Art's daughter, Roberta Mittelfdorf.
We have a combination of producers, writers, directors, actors, and some that wear more than one hat.
And you'll find right now in the dining room you've got a couple of actors.
You have different writers and...
My name is Bob Orci.
George Strayton.
And who do you write for?
I'm a feature writer, so whoever wants to pay me.
Have you worked on anything that we would know?
We managed to work on the show ""Xena: Battle Warrior Princess,"" or whatever.
Later I find out he's being a little modest.
Bob wrote the movies ""Mission Impossible 3,"" ""Transformers,"" and the upcoming ""Star Trek"" film.
And so you're here having a late breakfast, it looks like over there?
I think we're calling it brunch.
You're calling it brunch.
He's got breakfast and I've got lunch.
Okay.
So let's call it brunch.
And so what are you doing here right now?
I work here a lot.
This always been a lucky place for us in terms of generating ideas.

And actually, one of the things we've been doing here lately is generating ideas about how to keep our message alive and how to make the PR for the Writers Guild a little bit more effective, a little more proactive, and a little more outreaching to the studios.
And so what have you come up with here brainstorming?
Let's see.
We were just working on ""Don't Write Us Off."" We're going to sing all we are saying is give us a piece - to the tune of John Lennon.
What else do we have?
No Nerds, No Words.
No Nerds, No Words."" I like that.
Yeah.
Aside from poetic strike songs, George and Bob have come up with a serious plan.
Remember, this dispute is largely over how to divide up money from new media.

We're trying to - definitely trying to see it a little bit more from the studio's point of view, and I understand that they have legitimate concerns in terms of being afraid about the growth of the industry and in terms of being afraid of finding new revenue streams.
But we're all in that boat.
And the argument that the industry is the Titanic does not mean that because they're first class they're the only ones that get a lifeboat.
And rather than thinking them as the Titanic, we've got to think of it as why don't we team up and become partners in figuring out what new media really is.

The more information they share with us, the more information we share with them, the more we will both figure it out, as opposed to letting the fear of the industry collapsing divide us and having us horde our resources, horde our creativity, et cetera, et cetera.
Charles Ornstein is a reporter with the investigative news organization ProPublica.
The article he co-wrote on abusive nurses can be found at The Los Angeles Times Web site.
Charles, thank you.
Thanks for having me.
I spoke with Charles Ornstein earlier today.
And since then we have an update to his story.
Today the head of the nursing board submitted her resignation.
Welcome back to ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
I'm Jacki Lyden.
The biggest industrial bankruptcy in American history; if all goes as expected, that's what General Motors will declare tomorrow.
GM's move, along with Chrysler's earlier filing, will reshape the car business and a hefty chunk of the U.S.
economy.
Frank Langfitt, of course, covers the auto industry for NPR.
And Frank, thanks for joining us.
Happy to be here, Jacki.
So at this point, GM's bankruptcy seems inevitable.
Remind us of why that's so.
Well, this company is suffocating under a mountain of debt.
It owes retirees, bondholders - those are the people who have lent it money - and suppliers more than $60 billion.
And by just about all accounts, it can't get out from under all this debt without the help of a bankruptcy judge.
And how long is this bankruptcy procedure expected to take?

Well, Chrysler filed at the end of April, and a judge is going to rule tomorrow on a critical sale that could probably push a sort of new, healthier version of Chrysler out of bankruptcy in a couple of days.
Now that would be near-record time.
Chrysler, of course, was a dry run for GM, so this is pretty encouraging.
On the other hand, GM's a much bigger company, so it's going to take longer to deal with the partners that it has all over the world.
Now some of these bondholders and some of the dealers that GM is trying to cut, they're certainly going to fight this in court.

Treasury now is estimating it's going to be 60 to 90 days for kind of a new, leaner GM to come out of bankruptcy, but it's going to go back into a very competitive marketplace, and of course the economy's almost certainly still going to be in recession.
When GM comes out of bankruptcy, Frank, what's it going to look like?
What happens to its brand?
It's going to be dramatically smaller.
Saturn, Pontiac, Hummer, Saab, they're all going to be gone sooner or later, probably sooner.
They're going to be focusing on their core brands, the ones we know best: Chevy, Cadillac, Buick and, to a lesser extent, GMC Trucks.
